answers.answer: I agree with you that the minor disc problems are unlikely to explain your lower extermity symptoms.  From what you have described, it seems that a blood supply and drainage problem might be entertained.  Muscles that has problems with blood supply usually gets painful easily, much like that of cramps.  Blood supply and drainage can be evaluated through angiograms, or with venous doppler respectively.  You can discuss more of these tests when you get to meet your doctor next time.Regards and God bless.

Hi,Diabetes can also cause pain in calves and feet and tingling numbness. I hope a blood sugar test was also done to rule out diabetes.Obesity can also cause pain in the calves and feet due to increased pressure on legs, though I am not sure if that’s the case with you.I would suggest that you also get an Xray or a CT scan of your lower back done to rule out nerve compression at that level. Good luck!

question: I posted my symptoms the other day, been happening since February: numbness & tingling various parts of the body, feet, legs, hands, arms, face, head, muscle spasms throughout different parts of my body.  Went through the initial tests of CT of my head, x-rays of my cervical spine, then MRI (with and without contrast) on my head and cervical spine.  Went to the doctor yesterday, and basically he told me all they found was a couple of discs (cervical) out of alignment.  I can understand that affecting my head and arms, but not my feet and legs.  Doctor said I may have problems in my lumber spine also, but no further tests suggested.  The weird thing is I told him most of the consistent problems seem to be pain in my calves and feet (like I've run a marathon), something like RLS.  I can't take certain meds because of liver disease, so he prescribed aspirin therapy for now.  We'll see how that works.  If not, I guess I will speak to my PCD and see what else I can do and if there are any meds I can take to relieve the symptoms.  Any suggestions from anyone out there?
title: Now What?
